message_1: A group of 8 friends decided to go on a road trip and visit 5 different cities. They planned to split up into smaller groups and each group would visit one city together. Assuming there must be at least 2 people in each group, how many different ways could they split up?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the Stirling numbers of the second kind, which represent the number of ways to partition a set of n elements into k non-empty subsets. In this case, we have n = 8 friends and k = 5 cities.

The Stirling number of the second kind is denoted as S(n, k) and can be calculated using the following recurrence relation:

S(n, k) = k * S(n-1, k) + S(n-1, k-1)

with the base cases:

S(n, 1) = 1 for all n
S(n, n) = 1 for all n
S(n, 0) = 0 for all n > 0

Using this recurrence relation, we can find S(8, 5):

S(8, 5) = 5 * S(7, 5) + S(7, 4)

S(7, 5) = 5 * S(6, 5) + S(6, 4)
S(7, 4) = 4 * S(6, 4) + S(6, 3)

S(6, 5) = 5 * S(5, 5) + S(5, 4)
S(6, 4) = 4 * S(5, 4) + S(5, 3)
S(6, 3) = 3 * S(5, 3) + S(5, 2)

S(5, 5) = 1 (base case)
S(5, 4) = 4 * S(4, 4) + S(4, 3)
S(5, 3) = 3 * S(4, 3) + S(4, 2)
S(5, 2) = 2 * S(4, 2) + S(4, 1)

S(4, 4) = 1 (base case)
S(4, 3) = 3 * S(3, 3) + S(3, 2)
S(4, 2) = 2 * S(3, 2) + S(3, 1)
S(4, 1) = 1 (base case)

S(3, 3) = 1 (base case)
S(3, 2) = 2 * S(2, 2) + S(2, 1)
S(3, 1) = 1 (base case)

S(2, 2) = 1 (base case)
S(2, 1) = 1 (base case)

Now we can fill in the values from the base cases and work our way up:

S(3, 2) = 2 * 1 + 1 = 3
S(4, 2) = 2 * 3 + 1 = 7
S(4, 3) = 3 * 1 + 3 = 6
S(5, 2) = 2 * 7 + 1 = 15
S(5, 3) = 3 * 6 + 7 = 25
S(5, 4) = 4 * 1 + 6 = 10
S(6, 3) = 3 * 25 + 15 = 90
S(6, 4) = 4 * 10 + 25 = 65
S(6, 5) = 5 * 1 + 10 = 15
S(7, 4) = 4 * 65 + 90 = 350
S(7, 5) = 5 * 15 + 65 = 140
S(8, 5) = 5 * 140 + 350 = 1050

So there are 1050 different ways for the 8 friends to split up into groups and visit the 5 cities.
